content.description:
From the guidebook: 

  Climb the first line of bolts (dead tree/log at base;) thin face climbing, on gray rock with white streaks.

Climb up talus to start, crank past the initial hang, and climb the face above. In light of the fall potential, and a choice of holds, some worse than they appear, getting the high first bolt may be precarious? Climb to the 2nd bolt, where most tend right to features, before moving back left to the belay.

From the guidebook: 

  Start on Scrambled Eggs to its first bolt, but instead of traversing right, climb the face leading straight up left to the leftmost fixed  belay.

From the guidebook: 

  Starting at ground level, climb the fractured, gray-white face... perhaps the best introductory beginner/warm-up route on the Patio?

For better or worse, the first route established on the main Patio Wall, Scrambled Eggs (5.8), is a traversing affair. Over time, other routes, each with their own fixed belay, have been added that share, or intersect through parts of, this traversing route. 

  Climb the traversing route that starts left, but climbs way right. First bolt is located right of   the Patio Boulder. Climb to bolt, and traverse way right, ending up three fixed belays over.

From the guidebook: 

  Climb to the white shelf-hole, surmount the bulge, and climb the featured face above.

From the guidebook: 

  Climb more gray rock with white streaks.  Jugs to pockets, funky crux at top getting to rim holds.

From the guidebook: 

  Start on Scrambled Eggs to its first bolt, but instead of traversing way right, climb the face leading straight up right, past a hump-like feature, to the middle fixed belay.

Crux is pulling a small overhang to start and getting established on face above at bolt 1. Move slightly right then up on improving holds to a pumpy stance right of bolt 2 (left hand clip). Go left then straight up on steep face with positive holds (strenuous) to anchor. C.F.I.T. stands for 'Controlled Flight Into Terrain,' an FAA/NTSB term used to to categorize aviation accidents. Don't let that scare you away from this bouldery but surprisingly well-protected route.
content.protection: Two protection bolts, equalized two-bolt rap/lower/toprope anchor. Third bolted line from the right end of Patio Wall.
content.location: Located right of Turtle and left of Screaming Witch. Scramble up a small ramp behind the two large trees just right of the central part of the wall, to an alcove below a small overhang.

content.description:
From the guidebook: 

  Climb the blocky face, with a tricky spot up high... starts above tree at base.

From guidebook: 

  Climb blocky breaks.  Locate starting holds immediately right of tree.  A somewhat harder start exists to the right.

(10 routes & variations from 5.7 to 5.10b, 9 boulder problems from VB to V4 / primarily   south facing aspects) 

  LetÂ’s go out to the patio to find an aesthetic gray wall with a cool boulder in front of it.   Currently, the Patio Wall is the last wall with bolted routes on the river side.
